habitat_description:
Southwest:
Native to the Himalayan Kasmir region, this species was introduced to the Hearst Ranch in San Luis Obispo county California (Barrett 1966). The species is free-ranging and reproducing apparently around the confines of the ranch's conservation easement within the Piedra Blancas/Santa Lucia mountains. Tahr use a mixture of valley foothill hardwoods and open grasslands, interspersed with rocky outcrops for protection. In native Himalaya habitat, rocky, wooded mountain slopes and rugged hills are preferred (Nowak and Paradiso 1983, [Hopkins et al. from CAWHR] based on Zeiner et al. 1990). A small free-ranging population exists in around Mt. Taylor region of Cibbola National Forest and the Water Canyon Wildlife Management Area of New Mexico accourding to the New Mexico Department of Game & Fish (New Mexico Fish & Game 2010)
